body: I tried what you suggested here yesterday, as documented [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/540).  It broke 20 unit tests that assumes object identity semantics  of `==`. I'll fix it later.

get it, thanks! We cannot use is operator either, because the underlying object are different(they share the same handle).  What we could do is to introduce a same_as function similar to C++ end that does the same testing
The conv2d_nchw is quite specially tuned for K80 card, which will launch quite a lot more threads with shared memory resources. They are not as good schedule for the mobile GPUs.
That sounds good. I also prefer leaving the syntax sugar `==` for logical equality operator. Will follow up this later.

1) Can I always use conv2d_hwnc even though it is not optimized for a
particular processor/platform?
2) How do I know whch one , ie conv2d_nchw or conv2d_hwnc is used in the
cuda_imagenet_bench.py
<https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/master/examples/benchmark/cuda_imagenet_bench.py>
?

Thanks,

On Thu, Oct 12, 2017 at 10:23 AM, Tianqi Chen <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> The conv2d_nchw is quite specially tuned for K80 card, which will launch
> quite a lot more threads with shared memory resources. They are not as good
> schedule for the mobile GPUs.
>

The imagenet bench always use the nchw one, the hnwc one is designed for the batch kernel in cuda. I think we can try to make the schedule more adjustable so it can adapt to more platforms as a future goal

Will wait for your new design.
I think if NNVM/TVM can take advantage of mobile GPU to speed up deep
learning, it will be enable more deep learning applications on mobile
devices.

Thanks,

Yeah, it's weird since `./tests/scripts/task_python_unittest.sh` passed on my machine. Will take a look later.
Now I get a repro.

I don't think it would be bring any measurable benefit in CPU or GPU since the zero initialization happens in registers or the first level cache. However, if the region to be initialized is large (a fairly large tensor) or the memory to be initialized is expensive to update, peeling the first iteration (and therefore, avoiding the zero initialization) could be beneficial. 
For now, this is not on my critical path so I close this issue.
resolved in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/550

Seems there is an error case
which output ? I've already written an output of opencl and rocm for gemm.
Then the code is good!

cc @Huyuwei @Laurawly @ZihengJiang @adityaatluri
Will also need refactor of nnvm to directly always use the topi.generic function after this is merged.
num_thread = target.max_num_threads is nice. It solves AMD opencl problem I [reported](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/530).

@tqchen if you set num_thread = target.max_num_threads, num_thread  will be something like 1024 for cuda and rocm(hip). Is that ok?

Shouldn't it be like min(512,  target.max_num_threads)?

Ah, I see this block in your commit, so no problem.
```
 elif target_name in ("cuda", "nvptx"):
             self.keys += ("cuda", "gpu")
             self.max_num_threads = 512
```
Solved by #556
please run it in `x64 Native Tools Command Prompt for VS`.
is this an environment variable issue?
@tqchen This should be added to the document. Which one is the relevant document?
normally not add vs to the environment variable. when necessary, start a console with the vs environment.

Automatic lookups can be considered, but it is hard to automatically  choose when there are multiple versions of visual studio.
Or just give a friendly hint.
I think if cl.exe is not found in the env, give a hint error message is a reasonable way to go. What I normally do is to add that to the env variable.
ok.i am add error message.

To enable Mali GPUs, we need to further mobile GPU options here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/target.py#L63

Note that most of the current cuda schedules need tweaks for the mali target. So additional registered function from topi is needed
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/558

I add one addiitonal target, "opencl" to set self.max_num_threads = 8  in
the target.py as below:

        elif target_name in ("opencl",):
            # For now assume rocm schedule for opencl
            self.keys += ("rocm", "gpu")
            self.max_num_threads = 8

However, I still got the same error is  Error, code=-55:
CL_INVALID_WORK_ITEM_SIZE.
The error above seems due to other issues than available GPU resources.

This is mainly due to fact that there is not yet effort to optimize schedule for opencl devices. We do expect that there should be topi/rocm(for amd gpus) and topi/mali (for mobile gpus)

I'd like to understand what errors you are seeing. 

One case I see not covered is `bool(EqualOp == EqualOp)`, it will fail since `EqualOp` does not have `same_as`(inherited from `NodeBase`).

````bash
In [1]: import tvm

In [2]: a = tvm.const(1)

In [3]: type(a)
Out[3]: tvm.expr.IntImm

In [4]: b = a == a

In [5]: type(b)
Out[5]: tvm.expr.EqualOp

In [6]: bool(b) # works since a has same_as as it's IntImm
Out[6]: True

In [7]: c = b == b # now let's compare EqualOp

In [8]: type(c)
Out[8]: tvm.expr.EqualOp

In [9]: bool(c) # fails since EqualOp does not have same_as
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-9-f5dcfc4a672a> in <module>()
----> 1 bool(c) # fails since EqualOp does not have same_as

/Users/weichen/workspace/deep-learning/tvm/python/tvm/expr.py in __bool__(self)
    161
    162     def __bool__(self):
--> 163         return self.__nonzero__()
    164
    165     def asnode(self):

/Users/weichen/workspace/deep-learning/tvm/python/tvm/expr.py in __nonzero__(self)
    158
    159     def __nonzero__(self):
--> 160         return self.a.same_as(self.b)
    161
    162     def __bool__(self):

AttributeError: 'EqualOp' object has no attribute 'same_as'
````
A framework developed by Apple for IOS.

The unit-test case was originally designed for in-source testing (by setting the PYTHONPATH).

In that this specific case we forced tvm to use runtime only library, but "libtvm_runtime.so" is not installed along libtvm.so in the setup script, thus causing the error. We can either install libtvm_runtime.so with the library, or allow this test to fail gracefully without actually triggering an error

The original error is caused because HalideIR prevents comparison among handle types. So an error will be raised when we do 

```python
x = tvm.var("x", "handle")
y = (x==x)
```
oh thanks
the warnings can be safely ignored. Mainly due to destructing order issues. If you encapsulate them in python function, it won't happen

I believe this is a transient failure, [the same failure](http://mode-gpu.cs.washington.edu:8080/blue/organizations/jenkins/dmlc%2Ftvm/detail/master/305/pipeline) happened for another commit. Please retry the Jenkins build.

Interesting. Looking at the failure fixed by a retry, the mismatch rate is [`0.0108506944444 `](http://mode-gpu.cs.washington.edu:8080/blue/organizations/jenkins/dmlc%2Ftvm/detail/master/305/pipeline/)

For my error, the mismatch rate is [`0.00542534722223 `](http://mode-gpu.cs.washington.edu:8080/blue/organizations/jenkins/dmlc%2Ftvm/detail/PR-567/2/pipeline/326)(which is half of `0.0108506944444`).
@sxjscience can you check if argmin's impl have some potential issue? It could also due to ties and undefined behavior
I'm not able to reproduce the error you pasted by reverting your commit in my local branch. But with https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/567, I think `==` should work as we expect most of the time.

> Submodule path 'tvm': checked out 'eb761f36302d24c740b77281ecdcdddb588edf36'

Depend on how you do your development. If you do insource development (setup PYTHONPATH), then it would be totally fine
this is a planned feature that is yet to be officially announced so please stay tuned
I'm interested in this too. Do you have any rough timeline on developing this feature or the required infrastructure?
All the elements are in, it is mainly effort of documentation and testing
cc @adityaatluri
that's great!
this is surpassed by #570

Math function is supported with #570, 2 failing tests resolved.
But found another failing test in test_topi_pooling.py

Updated to reflect the latest status.

The tag of pooling is not ELEMWISE, it can't be fused into depthconv.

f4 = tvm.build(s4, [Relu, pool], device) will work.

As @Huyuwei explained, pooling cannot be fused into elemwise so far.

@Huyuwei do you think if we could improve pooling to have a clear error message for this case? Like raise an RuntimeError?
discarding as `nose` will find those tests.
Yes, this is definitely a better error message
I have a patch on python side. But maybe it's better to alert on C++ side? So all language bindings will have this check automatically.
please fix the lint error, you can reproduce locally by make lint
fixed by #575
Thank you so much @Huyuwei @tqchen
@Laurawly @Huyuwei @icemelon9

**verify_conv2d_nchw(1, 128, 28, 128, 3, 1, 1)** and **verify_conv2d_nchw(1, 256, 14, 256, 3, 1, 1)** were failing because of too aggressive unrolling when unroll_explicit = True.

They were resolved by #576 .
closing this due to inactivities. Possibly an llvm rebuilt from source might help

The rest of failing tests cases were due to a large thread block size.
They were all resolved by #577.

We still do not know why rocm backend cannot handle thread block of size 512 or 728.

All unit tests are good now. Closing.

Yes, what matters is the keyword  "gpu" in `self.keys += ("rocm", "gpu")`
This will cause schedules registered under "gpu" to be called by opencl backend.

Please build with llvm support

Relu should be declared as placeholder. For the sequence of depthconv+scaleshift+relu+pool, two computing kernels are generated: fused_depthconv_scaleshift_relu, and pool. The output of the fused_depthconv_scaleshift_relu is the input of pool. Try this:

```python
Relu1 = tvm.placeholder((Relu.shape))
kernel_height = 1
kernel_width = 1
kernel = [kernel_height, kernel_width]
pool_type = 'avg'
pool= topi.nn.pool(Relu1, kernel, Stride, padding, pool_type)
s4 = topi.cuda.schedule_pool(pool)
f4 = tvm.build(s4, [Relu1, pool], device)
pool_tvm = tvm.nd.array(np.zeros(shape=get_const_tuple(pool.shape), dtype=pool.dtype), ctx)
timer_4 = f4.time_evaluator(f4.entry_name, ctx, number=1000)
tcost_4 = timer_4(relu_tvm, pool_tvm).mean
```
The existing schedule for AMD/CUDA GPUs do not work well on the ARM GPUs, and we will need independent schedules for them. For example, it is usually not helpful to take use of shared memory
